text: On tap @ Barleycorn. This is a deeper dark brown looking one, almost deep copper and quite cloudy in the glass. A huge almost creamy khaki head leaving nice lacings and dots down the glass. The nose has tones of sweet dark candied sugar, earthy fruit. I get a little bit of alcohol, warming, pleasant. Tastes quite good this. It has a good almost acidic sweetness. Lots of dark candied sugar heres. Its really smooth and creamy in the mouth and therefor somewhat soft on the carbonation. Traces of both cold coffee and chocolate wrapper. In the end it turns more nutty in a way with a taste of burnt raisins. Just had the #3 in the series and enjoyed it, but this is even tastier. 16.06.2015
A cloudy, brown pour with an off-white head. The aroma has bready malt, raisin, and cloves. It has a medium body with lively carbonation. The taste is tart with a mouthwatering finish.

Pours a pretty pale brown for a dubnel with a beige rim on top that leaves some lacing. Nose is of grapes, alcohol and burnt sugar. Taste is of caramel, toffee, more burnt sugar and some dark fruits. Just too caramel-forward for me to give it a thumbs up. Moderate body and carbonation. A pretty good "dubbel" that is just lacking the classic dark fruits too much.

Bottle 750ml.
Pours brown/mahogany with low beige head. Aroma is of caramel, metal, malt, molasses, belgian yeast. Taste is of caramel, metal, figs, some bitterness, slight acidity, molasses, belgians yeast. Palate: Full bodied, light-medium carbonation. Overall: Good dubbel, nice malt features.

Bottle (750 ml), shared by czar, thanks! BB 09/09/2017 so its quite a bit old already. Hazy dark copper with a small bubbly beige head leaving little lacing. Aroma is of caramel, dried raisins/fruits, molasses notes and mild spiciness. Taste is semi-sweet, dried fruits, caramel/brown sugar and mild spiciness. Medium body. Moderate-medium carbonation. Dried raisins finish. Really well preserved for an old Dubbel. Complex, flavorful and drinkable.

corked bottle. pours unclear light brown-orange with a small light beige cap offering some retention and lacing. candied caramelized sugars, tons of toffee - toffee apple perhaps; spicy berry fruitiness, raisins, lightly phenolic yeast, spices. almost bright carbonation, light to medium body, semi-sweet woodsy-spicy finish. another solid dubbel by ommegang.

Bouteille avec un BB du 09/09/2017. Robe brune-ambrée trouble avec un petit voile de mousse et quelques petites particules en suspension. Arômes de baies confites, malt caramélisé, carré aux dattes, cerise, épices festives, sucre dorge. En bouche, caramel amer, baies confites, sucre dorge. Fond dépices sucrées, butterscotch, anis, malt légèrement grillé. Texture huileuse et collante, corps moyen à rond.

750 ml corked and crowned bottle. Translucent mahogany brown color. Small creamy beige head. Aroma is redolent of dark dried fruit, Demerara sugar and overripe plums. Flavor follows nose with additional notes of burnt caramel and cloves. Silky mouthfeel with complex dark fruity malt notes. Finishes with rich chewy malt and subtle hops. Very nicely done. A tasty Dubbel Ale.

Dark ruby with a lingering beige head. Powerful ripe dark fruit, date, brown sugar, raisin, caramel malt. Flavor is similar with a bit of spice and light toasted malt. Faint alcohol heat that pairs well with the mildly spiced profile. A winner.
750 ml bottle purchased at Total Wine Pembroke Pines, FL for $10.99. Very good.

October 12th, 2014 - Valor Moghulis! And yes, this was had during a new episode of HBOs Game of Thrones, though I dont think any of the characters actually used this iconic phrase in the episode. Dark and shadowy, its link to the organization and its surreptitious susurrations around the main characters is made clear. The aroma is tangy, with the sweet side of red bordeaux grapes, and a slight umami note to give the grape some savory depth. Additional sips reveal additional flavors, like a touch of leather uncoiling as the beer warms, or beef jerky and its attending spices. Blueberries and blackberries appear on the back end, as if caught while trying to slip away, arrested in panic and with just a low touch of sweetness. The flavor strongly resembles a dubbel, with wood and cheese and lots of umami to pass around. The berries make a return along with apple juice and cherry juice to top off the flavors. Listing all these tastes make it sound sweet, and it might be closer to a dessert than an appetizer, but the rungs of umami layers provide the balance and support on which to hang some sugary sweet touches without making this cloying. How delightfully piercing.

Draft. Cloudy deep amber body with a frothy, off-white head. Aroma of plum, raisin, leather, toasted grain. Hint of licorice. The flavor is moderately sweet and lightly bitter. It finishes lightly to moderately sweet and lightly to moderately bitter. Medium body, watery/velvety, lively carbonation. Ripe fruits, light mustiness and sweet malt backbone yet dry enough and lightly bitter enough to keep everything in balanced.

UPDATED: NOV 18, 2016 From a corked bottle into the Game of Thrones glass. Pours brown with large head and lace. Aroma of dark malts, caramel, halva. Significant carbonation and medium mouthfeel. Flavors of roasty malts, burnt malts, slight licorice, old roasted peanut oil. Overall rich, full bodied, a little hot in the alcohol that dissapates somewhat with time...decent but with some so-so funky (borderline oxidized) flavors.

Bottle (BB July 2018).

Head is initially average sized, frothy, light brown, mostly lasting.
Body is hazy dark amber to medium brown.

Aroma is moderately malty (caramel, roasted nuts, toasted grain), lightly to moderately yeasty (basement), with notes of clove, licorice, brown sugar, orange peel.

Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is lightly sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, moderately bitter, spicy.

Medium to full body, watery/velvety/syrupy texture, lively carbonation, lightly to moderately alcoholic. 

Quite clovey-spicy (almost as if spices were added, as they do with their year-round dubbel) and fairly acidic as well, two things that make it hard to get really enthusiastic about this one. The aftertaste similarly seems spiced, and it becomes fatiguing fairly quickly from that despite being well-balanced for the most part. Its clean, solid, and nicely made, it just doesnt excite me.

Bottled 7/18/16 Deep crimson. Off-beige foam exhibits near 5-star retention. Maltcenrtic nose of black plum, tobacco, vanilla, hazelnut, raisin, and suggestive melanoidins. Hints of aniseed (Spalt?) and dried leather. Fluffy and expansive carbonation. Elegant and deceptively weightless maltiness delivers a mouthwatering smattering of springy tobacco and cookie notes on initial taste. A tinge of vanilla further softens the languidly evolving maltiness, enriching the squeaky clean fermentation with extraordinary textural richness including silky melanoidins. Nutty and claylike yeast imparts Abbeylike character without affecting the sparkling attenuation. Distant German-hop-derived candied fennel suggestions are seamlessly integrated within the malt-dense core. An "airy" and peppery dimension keeps the sugars in check, unveiling a blindingly bright assortment of zingy rock candy and perfectly ripe plums as it gracefully sweeps the palate. Suggestive creamed java attests to the skillful malt extraction, as a buried snap of candied pecans and breadcrust bring additional contrast to the richer elements. Masterfully balanced finish is semi-dry and gently coarse in its pepperiness, with a sweet tobacco and dusty yeast punctuation. As with the tripel in this series, this is absolutely bang-on to style, and simply top-notch nectar. "Purity" is the descriptor that repeatedly comes to mind when describing the malt character in this, and the level of sophistication found here is not to be overstated. It has all the complexity I look for in the style, yet never feels overcrowded, and the high degree of attenuation, coupled with the exquisite balance, is a divine match and just makes this effortless to throw back. Obviously German noble hops, to boot. Im so heartened that Ommegang has been elevating their game these past few years and still occasionally churns out some unapologetically traditional styles like this one, sans the bells and whistles. Hats off!

text: Bottle: &nbsp Brownish, a bit of a ruby hue, thin to moderate light beige head, little lacing. &nbsp Musty and barnish soft bready nose. &nbsp Slight dark pitted fruit. &nbsp Seems like a moderate Belgian Dubbel. &nbsp Backside has the same barnish and musty bready notes with some mild dark pitted fruit. &nbsp Seems pretty Belgian, but also somewhat pedestrian. &nbsp Moderate body and mouthfeel. &nbsp Clean finish. &nbsp Very moderate or average example, but fairly good. &nbsp Wished it were a bit more pronounced/brighter, but otherwise fairly decent.

Pours clear ruby red-brown with a 1-finger mocha colored head. Nutty malt aroma beneath notes of apple and maybe cherry. Body is medium-to-full and lightly syrupy. Dry finish. Flavor is earthy, mixed with nutty malt. Fruit notes show at the back.
Bottle. Original spicy aroma, caramel, dried fruit. Taste: wine with dried pear, dried figs, spicy and very cool.

750ml bottle 7/25/16 (Binnys Downers Grove)-46° in Trappist Glass-Pours a ruby red with a small off white head. Aroma of sweetness, yeast, malt, and caramel. Taste of the same with a bit of spice. this medium to full bodied brew is well balanced and quite tasty.
The aroma is fruity and malty with floral hops. The appearance is deep amber with a big head. The taste is like the aroma. The palate is smooth. Overall good.

Pours a reddish brown with a frothy beige head. Aroma is sweet caramel and belgian candy sugar. Some purple fruit in here as well. Taste is a little sickly sweet, plum, raisin, caramel. Nice beer but too sweet for me.

(Ommegang Game of Thrones #4 - Valar Morghulis) Bottle 750 ml from Summer Santa, thanks! Served into a big tulip, ABV 8%
Brown red ccolour on the body, kind of murky, with a big beige head on top, thick and with good retention.
Aroma has red and dark fruits, , alcohol, ripe pears.
Taste is mildly sweet with flavours f dark fruits, red stewed fruits, ripe pears, light berries, alcohol, light yeast.
Medium body with carbonation on the high siide.
Nice.

750ml bottle, courtesy of an Easter guest. Poured a slightly murky chestnut brown with a one finger creamy khaki head. Some lace. Dark fruits and sweetness on the aroma. Hint of maple. Sweet flavors of brown sugar, candied cherries, a hint of molasses and a light spice. Medium bodied with a fairly high level of carbonation. Finishes a bit dry. Tasty!
Tap at Alewife Queens, New York. Colour is brown with very small white head. Aromas and flavours: Ripe fruits, dry fruits, caramel, Belgian yeast and malts. Pretty average dubbel IMO.

Bottle. Pours tawny brown. Aroma is bready and cookie malts, toffee, cherries and plums, and some woody notes. Flavor matches the aroma and is nicely malt forward with good yeast esters and dark fruit sweetness throughout before drying out at the end. Medium/full body.

From a bottle. Pours opaque copper brown with a creamy, bubbly beige head. Tastes like dried fruits, toasted malt, toffee, and prunes. Light/medium body and carbonation. Smells like dried fruits, toasted malt, toffee, prunes, and raisins.

From notes (06/27/2015). Straight-down-the-middle Belgian flavor and aromas, with fruity yeast esters and raisin malt flavor. Solid beer, and speaking from experience it pairs well with GoT marathons.

So, so good. The second time I had it wasnt quite as good as the first time I had it, so it loses a tiny bit on the consistency side, but make no mistake--this is easily the best Game of Thrones beer that Ommegang makes, and its probably because its so close to their fantastic flagship brew, Abbey Ale, which is also a dubbel.

on tap @ Vino Bellissimo / Lima OH --- Clear brown color, beige head, blobs and spots of lace. Taste is semi-sweet toffee and malt that grow bigger through a lightly carbonated swallow. Maybe a little dark fruit here, maybe cloves, but the finish arrives with hardly a trace of hops. A reasonably good brew.

750 ml corked and caged bottle. Clear deep ruby copper, large lasting fine tan foam. Aroma of caramel/toffee malts and dark fruits. Rich sweet caramel/ toffee malt taste, riper dark fruits, some hints of cocoa later on. Softer carbonation, medium bodied, lightly hopped. Mediocre for Ommegang. NFL (Not For Lagerboys)

En bouteille. Couleur cuivrée foncé avec épaisse mousse beige. Arômes de sucre dorge, alcool. Goût malt caramel, sucre dorge, épices et levures belges. Palais rond, très enrobant, belle chaleur, subtil sucre résiduel avec faible effervescence. Cest une bonne bière dessert, style porto, un délice.

750ml bottle. Pours a lightly hazy garnet with some sediment and a one finger head that is an attractive tan/orange hue. Aromas of raisin, prune, light molasses, a faint hint of spearmint, and a note that makes me think raisin bran muffins. Sweet with a lightly acidic apple sauce note (Weird? Yes. Though I have never tasted such a thing in a beer, it is not unwelcome.) clove, light Concorde grape, with faint earthiness that leads into lighter maltier notes, more dried fruit, and a pleasant clove note in the finish. Its tasty, and honestly that weird apple sauce note that leads into the clove kind of makes it for me. Thumbs up.

Bottle - 750mL corked and caged. Muddy copper with a tall, frothy tan head. Aroma is sweet and fruity with caramel, sweet malt, dark fruits, candi sugar and yeast notes. Taste is sweet malt, dark fruit, candi sugar, caramel, light cocoa and Belgian yeast. Body is medium with a strong, prickly carbonation. Ends with more caramel, dark fruit, sweet malt, dark bread, candi sugar and yeast. Not bad.

Aroma is lush with red malts, light toastiness, subdued sweetness and a herbal tone from the hops....lush, full bodied, roasty, malty with enough hop balance to to take you into the middle of the profile which hits with a fairly complex - finish is more dry and 2 dimensional with roasty malt anf herbal hopping - nice abbey brew, not a hint of alcohol on the palate

This beer arrived at the door with a few friends... Full mouthfeel of malt and grain surrounded by some sweet Candi sugar. Yup, a Belgian strain of yeast. A nice spike of spice in second half of mouthfeel. loong slow finish.. Yum.
Poured from the bottle a cloudy chocolate with a fine toffee head. Nose is licorice, fruity. First taste has a cherry sweetness thats not over the top. Floral yuminess shared with good friends.
Purvis Cellars bottle(4-Nov-15)Ripe fruit,toffee aroma.Brown-red,low head&suds lace.Caramel,ripe fruit,herbal flavour.Ripe fruit light spice& toffee tangy aftertaste.
Caramel malt aroma. Murky brown colour fair head and lacing. Malt caramel fruit flavour. Smooth lingering palate.
Very tasty beer from an amazing show, cool concept and overall very solid dubel. Nice caramel color with Malty taste, everything you would expect from a beer like this
Tasted at Kansas City Beerfest at Union Station October, 2015. I had so many that this rating might be a bit off. ;)
Pours a nice dark reddish amber color. Aromas of fruit, and some other hints, maybe some spices, maybe caramel. Flavor is a bittersweet, malty, and a hint of hops with a nice bittersweet finish.
Poured a mahogany with a big billowing beige head. Aroma was musty bakers chocolate with a hint of dark fruits. Tasted the same. Mediocre at best. Glad I got it on sale at $4.99 a corky.

Boring dubbel for me. Pours a light burgundian brown with a thick beige head. THe nose is fruity, toffee and caramel malts and a pinch of spice. Rich but subdued with a light finish, mild raisin and prune notes. Just flat and monotone.
I think their best and hits the spot, getting through the entire bomber myself over a long lunch. Good malting though its sweet for sure.
NOt was special as most would think. It was nice and quite thick. Not so Belgish but still good with cheese and other nice charcuterie.

Bottle. Heavy malt aromas of cookie and caramel, light to moderate cooked orange for the hops, moderate dough for the yeast, with date, dried cherry, brown sugar, maple syrup and fresh fig. Head is small, frothy, light beige with good lacing and good leg, and is mostly diminishing. Color is murky medium red/brown. Flavor starts moderately sweet and acidic, then finishes lightly sweet, moderately acidic, and lightly to moderately bitter. Palate is on the fuller side of medium, oily, with a fizzy carbonation. A perfectly made Abbey Dubbel from Ommegang.
Poured from 750mL bottle (aged for not quite a year). Amber brown with beige head. Lots of raisin and dark fruits, brown sugar, and little caramel. Finishes medium dry.

Pours copper with a large head.
Nose shows caramel, toffee, sultanas, prunes and soft spicy notes.
Similar flavours. Quite sweet with bready and sultana notes.
Carbonation is pretty aggressive.

Similar to Ommegang's regular dubbel, but without the cloves and apples up front. This has more molasses and sweeter esters, and is smoother than the regular dubbel. It pours maroon/brown with a lot of head, the aroma is brown sugar and dark bread. The creeping clove that can come to dominate the regular release isn't here at all, it's replaced by sugar. Typically That means I wouldn't like it as much, but I enjoyed every drop. This thing has a malt backbone that can stand up to the sweetness. It never became liquid candy, never wore out its welcome. This is a fine beer.

Sampled from a 750 ml brown bottle this beer poured an orange-brown color with an enormous foamy orange-tan head that lingered forever and left great lacing. The aroma was sweet, mlaty, dark fruits, cola, yeast and a hint of spice. The flavor was malty, dark fruits, cola, yeast, a bit herbal and a touch medicinal. Long finish. Moderately full bodied. Interesting.

Bottle: Poured a cloudy brown color ale with a medium size foamy head with OK retention and light lacing. Aroma of light spices with quite a bit of caramelized malt and residual sugar notes. Taste is also dominated by heavy caramelized malt with quite a bit of residual sugar notes with light spices notes. Body is full with medium to good carbonation. Short on attenuation and little bit too heavy for my taste.
Drank many months ago. Good Dubbel, with plenty of depth of malt and complexity from fermentation. Enjoyable.
Pours copper brown with large tan head. Initial smell is toffee and sugar. Taste is toffee, sugar and faint cloves. Tan lacing persistent throughout. Just a fantastic beer!

Bottle thanks to my wife stephrocks: Poured a dark brown color with a tan head. Aroma was dark fruits, toffee, and malt. Taste was high fermented fruit, alcohol tang, rich malts, and caramel. Finish was dry.
Bottle from Whole Foods Market in Redwood City, CA. Caramel, sweet malts with slight bitterness. Expected this to be WAY OVER THE TOP (for obvious reasons). Not very memorable.

Cloudy red brown with generous frothy tan head. Sweet aromas - toffee, caramel, belgian yeast, cherries, raisins, spices, fresh bread. The taste is plums, cherries, toffee, spices, lightly toasted bread. Very light hop bitterness and dryness in the finish. Medium bodied. Pretty good dubbel.
Looks exactly like what a beer a character on the show would be drinking. Feeling very hipster drinking this ... in a good way. Overall a pretty satisfying Dubbel Ale.

Bottle 750ml @ Hotel room, Webers, Ann Arbor, MI
Pours clear deep reddish brown with a beige head. Aroma has notes of malt, caramel, dried fruits, yeast and hint of licorice and alcohol. Taste is medium sweet and light bitter with a long warm, malty, caramel, dried fruity and yeasty finish. Body is full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

Bottle, 75cl corked. It pours a dense, two-ginger dark beige head over a clear, chestnut colored body. The aroma has lots of dried fruits, some nuts and roasted malts, some hints of chocolate and theres also some bread crust. Its full-bodied, smooth and lightly warming on the palate, with a good of bitterness and a touch of resins. Dried fruits, bready caramel, some Norwegian style brown cheese, a little caramel note and nuts in the flavor, all lasting for a good while, with the bitterness balancing the sweetness very well. A well brewed dubbel with a lot of good flavors and aromas, still I feel something is missing, pity I cant put my finger on it. 150614

750ml bottle poured into a Westmalle chalice. Deep brown with a ton of tan creamy head. Strong aroma of dark fruits and candy filled the air immediately after popping the cork. Flavor is figs and candy sugar. Very effervescent. Lots of alcohol and a weird basement-y flavor present in the finish. Tasty brew until the odd stale finish.

Bottle. Deep maroon hue, slightly cloudy, with a dense yet fizzy head the color of beach sand. Beautiful, candy-like Belgian ester aroma -- strawberries, bubble-gum, toffee, cherry, a little brown sugar, a backdrop of earthy hops, beefy alcohol and a little rye. It smells a lot like an old-fashioned. The flavor adds sugary peach and a twist of orange to this melange. The bodys velvety and soft; the finish is surprisingly dry and bitter. Very nice, flavorful and complex dubbel.

Pretty nice pop behind the cork, Rocky off white head, which slowly falls to a more creamy texture. Cloudy ruddy red body. Malty aroma. Flavor is exceptional. Lots of woody character to the malt. Not overly happy. My favorite of the GofTh series to date.
Bottle. Deep chestnut brown color with a tan head. Aroma is caramel, toffee, fruit cake and a hint of cloves. Taste is caramel with a nice hop bitterness.

Aroma is nice, some cinnamon suggestions, clove, and sweet liqueur super smooth booze combined with fruity esters. Pours amber brown with a tan head. Aroma is earthy, basement, plum, raisin and caramel. Taste is sweet with mild bitter/tartness. Medium bodied, smooth and overall a solid dubbel.

Pours a dark amber colour, almost copper, with a frothy beige head, good retention and some nice fluffy lacing. Aromas of dark fruits (plums, raisins), caramel, farm yeast and with time, lots of fresh apples. There is a sharp weird hop bites in the taste over the fruits and caramel malts. It gives the mouth a metallic feel which is not as good. Hints of bananas from the yeast in the aftertaste. Not the best Dubbel, but overall not bad. Poured from a 750ml bottle. This is a damn fine dubbel. Yeasty, bready, malty, fruity aroma. The flavor is dried fruits, malty, yeasty, slight yeast bite, fruity. I really enjoyed this beer.

Rich fruity esther aroma, mahogany tinted light brown color. Solid dark tan head. Some sweetness in the flavor mixing with dark, aged fruit -- dates, raisin. Medium body. It has that "Ommegang yeast" quality. The alcohol is well hidden. Enjoyable.

750 ml bottle corked and caged. Pours a darker brown with a beige head of foam. The aroma has a nice raisin and ester profile, with a bit of spices as well. The taste is sweet and lightly estery. Medium body and thick, low carbonation mouthfeel.
Ruby red pour, small off white head that vanishes. Has elements of pitted fruit, clove, light sweetness from start to finish. Light body.

Presentation: It was poured from a big corked and caged bottle into a tulip glass. The label lists the abv at 8% and there is a nice short description of the beer. 
Appearance: It has a cloudy look in its deep reddish brown body. The head on top is tall tan and long lasting which makes some nice lacing on the glass as I sip it down.
Smell: The aroma has nice yeasty fruity esters. It is full of juicy fruit and light bready sweetness. 
Taste/Palate: The fruity flavor notes really pop out on this one. I get notes of apple peels, red pears, tart/sour cherry and almond ring coffee cake.

La bouche, elle, est franchement plus fruitée que sucrée ; une finale houblonnée définit les derniers instants. Notes de baies rouges, canneberges surtout, et de caramel au fur et à mesure quelle se réchauffe. Belle bière, joliment complexe, mais aurait pu présenter une texture plus riche.
Bottle from craft. Nice notes of caramel malt, brown sugar, yeast, toffee and plum. Really blended well.
Bottle courtesy of Ed, thank you sir! Clear amber brown color. Roasty cocoa aroma. Taste is chocolate brownies. Hodor!

Bottle enjoyed with the season premiere. Almost clear deep brown liquid with a ruby hue and small medium moussy light brown head. Aroma of raw sugar, raisins, toffee, dried fruit, wort caramel and light port wine. Taste is light to medium sweet and light bitter with notes of raw sugar, toffee, raisins and light earth. Medium bodied with medium carbonation. Quite nice.

Really good brew. Appearance is like other GOT beers with a creamy long lasting head, some lace, this one is a tad darker with a slightly hazy dark honey color. Aroma is toffee, toast, fruit, yeast, wine. Flavors similar to nose, sweet and tangy up front with just enough bitterness to balance. Excellent body thats soft yet buzzy. Nothing wrong with this beer at all. Very easy drinking.

Bottle into tulip glass. Pours a muddy looking brown colour with a tan head. Aroma is caramel and ripe stone fruits. Taste is burnt sugar ripe stone fruits and a little alcohol. Nice beer.

A sharing drink, because the quantity per-bottle is perhaps a bit much for a single person, unless you manage to store it and drink over multiple occasions.

Well to start, this beer sucks. It really sucks. Its also the second time Ive bought a big bottle from Ommegang to have with a holiday meal and been utterly disappointed in the result. Poured from bottle into a pint glass
 Appearance  The beer pours a dark brownish mahogany color with a one finger of tan colored head. The head fades rather rapidly at first and then leaves a bit of persistent foam, which slowly fades to leave a moderate level of lace on the sides of the glass.
 Smell  The aroma is big of a dark fruit smell with tons of cherry, raisin and fig. Along with these smells comes some other fruity aromas of a light fruit nature with some apricot and pineapple both being there. There is some yeasty aromas as well as a little bit of a more banana and wheaty smell. With just a hint of booze hitting the nose as well, one is left with a rather fruity sweet, but very pleasurable aroma overall.
 Taste  The taste begins a bit drier then would have been anticipated from the nose, but by no means dry overall. There is a good showing of dark fruit flavor of cherry and plum, complimented by some other fruits of apricot and peach as well as a little bit of a toasted bready taste. As the flavor advances the darker fruits gain just a little bit of strength, while the lighter fruits gain even more. While the darker fruits remain the dominate sweeter flavor, the light fruits, with some candied sugar flavors joining in later, do give it a run for its money in terms of dominate sweet flavor. A yeast cake taste really brings on its potency at the end of the taste and is joined by a little bit of a more rum like booze flavor. The mix of flavors that is left at the end, leaves a nice fruity and robust fruited dubbel flavor to linger on the tongue.
 Mouthfeel  The body of the beer is on the average side with a carbonation level that is on the slightly higher side. For the fruit flavors the higher carbonation level does rather nicely creating a rather crisper more refreshing feel, but with that said, the average body does well for the lightly roasted, boozy and yeasty flavors for the brew accentuating them in light of the fruit. Overall, this was rather well done and made for a good sipping dubbel.
 Overall  A rather nice, slightly more fruity dubbel. Another good brew by Ommegang, and while no Abbey ale, it is quite fantastic and worth a try.

Appearance: Creamy eggshell white head with a dark hazelnut brown color. The body is hazy to the point where I cant even see carbonation.

Aroma: It has a very sweet candy-like aroma with notes of apple, figs, and banana. There is only a slight hint of alcohol. It doesnt have a huge amount of Belgian yeast character on the nose, but just enough to make it identifiably Belgian and it is pleasant.

Taste: It is a very nice, clean, dubbel. There is a fig flavor, along with some brown sugar, some sweet alcohol flavor (not burning or overpowering), and a light woody character in the background. There is a light banana chip flavor in the aftertaste.

Mouthfeel: The mouthfeel is awesome. It is perfectly smooth, great carbonation, and it coats the mouth with flavor without being overly sweet or sticky. Its perfect.

Overall: This is a very good dubbel that stands well by itself, even without the book or television reference in the packaging. I strongly believe that anyone who appreciates Belgian style beers will enjoy this and I recommend giving it a shot. What I really like about this beer is that it is nice and mellow. I dont know the background on this beer but it really tastes like it was aged before it hit the shelves because the flavors are a bit subdued but meld very well together. In any event I really enjoy this.
